headline.main: Pounds Lost on Atkins Diet May Quickly Return

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses weight gain in Americans and how it relates to two new studies published in New England Journal of Medicine on possible risks and benefits of Atkins Diet; article notes Americans eat more fat and carbohydrates than 30 years ago and, most importantly, more calories, while general fitness levels have declined; people on Atkins diet do show quick weight loss and new study finds it does not have negative impact on cholesterol; long terms effects, however are not known and many participants begin gaining weight back within six months of starting Atkins Diet; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The Atkins diet gained a modicum of respectability this month when scientists reported that two clinical trials found the high-fat, high-protein, low-carbohydrate diet did not cause disastrous increases in serum cholesterol and even reduced one or two cardiac risk factors. The studies, reported in The New England Journal of Medicine, compared the effects on weight loss and cardiovascular risk factors of the Atkins plan with the conventional low-fat, low-calorie diet recommended by most health experts. Both diets resulted in weight loss, but participants on the Atkins diet lost more weight, faster.

docs.abstract: Article on rising number of Long Island teens who are working out with personal trainers; International Health, Racquet & Sportsclub Assn research director William Howland Jr says 6-to-18-year-olds are second fastest-growing market for health clubs; Ira Frank, Larry Samuels and other Long Island trainers comment; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: MICHELLE SHNEYDEROV, 15, said she sometimes cries when she thinks about her figure. She's 5-foot-5 and 132 pounds, not nearly as ''skinny'' as her friends, she said. When her best friend, Jamie Rothman, also 15, invited her to join the Rothman family on their annual spring vacation in Aruba, Michelle decided she needed to get in shape. She hired Ira Frank, a personal fitness trainer. Actually, Michelle and Jamie decided to share six sessions at Atlantis, a fitness studio near their homes in Atlantic Beach, and their parents agreed to pick up the $60-an-hour cost. Mr. Frank, a certified personal trainer and the club's owner, put them through a vigorous hour-long workout twice a week. The routine included abdominal crunches using a balance ball, walking lunges for the legs, a series of arm exercises and nutritional advice.
